quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Mercor is the fastest-growing company in history to go from 1 to $500 million in revenue. They did this in 17 months, less than a year and a half.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for hypergrowth that sets a high bar and invites analysis of the underlying drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: They've never had a customer churn, their net retention is over 1,600%, and they're on a nine-figure revenue run rate.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific retention and revenue metrics that signal extreme product-market fit and expansion dynamics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we talk about the increasing value and importance of evals, the landscape of AI training companies like Mercor, and why they've become so important and valuable, how Brendan discovered this opportunity, his insights on what product market fit looks like, the core tenets he's instilled within his organization that have allowed him to build the fastest growing company in history, what people writing evals for labs are actually doing day to day, which skills and jobs are going to last the longest with the rise of AI, why he doesn't think we'll see AGI or superintelligence anytime soon, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A roadmap of the episode’s practitioner-relevant themes, including evals, PMF, organizational tenets, and a contrarian view on AGI timelines.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Mercor, if you haven't heard of them, helps AI labs and AI companies hire experts to help them train their models using AI.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A succinct description of the business model connecting expert labor to AI model improvement via training workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A practical expectation-setting insight for SaaS builders about when enterprise requirements inevitably show up.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a product-selection heuristic: choose infrastructure that minimizes cognitive load and accelerates shipping.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Warrant's product is based on a groundbreaking authorization system called Zanzibar, which was originally designed for Google to power Google Docs and YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete example of leveraging proven, hyperscale design patterns (Zanzibar) for enterprise authorization needs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of the core tradeoff to optimize for in authorization systems: scale plus flexibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Instead of dreaming up big ideas, talking to customers, and crafting a strategy, you're drowning in spreadsheets and roadmap updates and you're spending your days basically putting out fires.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A sharp diagnosis of a common product-team failure mode that practitioners can use to recognize when process is crowding out real product work.

quotes.topic_title: The era of evals explained
quotes.text: If the model is the product, then the eval is the product requirement document.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A crisp framework for treating evals as the core spec that defines what “good” looks like for an AI system.

quotes.topic_title: The era of evals explained
quotes.text: And reinforcement learning is becoming so effective that once they have an eval, they can help climb it.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Highlights a practical lever: progress accelerates dramatically once success is measurable via a solid eval.

quotes.topic_title: The era of evals explained
quotes.text: If you look at just how fast people were able to saturate Olympiad Math once they focused on it, how fast we're even saturating SWE-bench once we focus on it.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Concrete examples showing how quickly capabilities improve when the target is clearly defined and optimized against.

quotes.topic_title: The era of evals explained
quotes.text: And so in many ways, the barrier to applying agents the entire economy to automate every workflow is how do we measure success? How do we eval it?
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: the bottleneck to automation isn’t models—it’s specifying and measuring outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: How enterprises should approach evals
quotes.text: Yeah. I think that for enterprises especially, the core way to think about it is how can they build a test or systematic way to measure how well AI automates their core value chain?
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Defines a practical enterprise eval framework: measure AI against the company’s value chain, not generic benchmarks.

quotes.topic_title: How enterprises should approach evals
quotes.text: So if it's an architecture firm that's producing these architecture diagrams of what they provide to their end customer, how can they effectively measure that?
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Grounds eval design in concrete customer deliverables, making it easier to build tests that reflect real business value.

quotes.topic_title: How enterprises should approach evals
quotes.text: And each company has its own value chain or maybe a handful of them if it's a multi-product company.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Highlights that evals should be tailored per value chain (and per product), rather than one-size-fits-all.

quotes.topic_title: How enterprises should approach evals
quotes.text: And just thinking about how they measure that is the prerequisite to really effectively applying AI throughout their entire business.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Emphasizes measurement-first as a gating step before broad AI deployment across the enterprise.

quotes.topic_title: How enterprises should approach evals
quotes.text: Sarah tweeted, "Evals equals your new marketing."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Introduces a provocative, counterintuitive framing that evals can become a differentiator akin to marketing.

quotes.topic_title: Evals as marketing and sales collateral
quotes.text: Yeah. Well, it ties to what I said earlier about how if the model is the product, evals are the PRD, but also subsequently the sales collateral, right?
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A crisp framework for treating evals as both the product spec and outward-facing go-to-market material.

quotes.topic_title: Evals as marketing and sales collateral
quotes.text: Because evals are what you give to researchers to show them what they should be building and going on, but they're also the way that you demonstrate the efficacy of capabilities.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Highlights evals as a dual-use tool: aligning internal development and proving value externally.

quotes.topic_title: Evals as marketing and sales collateral
quotes.text: And historically, everyone's been pointing to these academic evals of PhD level reasoning with GPQA, Humanity's Last Exam, or Olympiad Math, but now it's moving towards the capabilities that people practically care about of how do we get models to automate the way that we build a software platform or automate the way that we do an investment banking analysis.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Captures the shift from academic benchmarks to domain-specific evals tied to real customer workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Evals as marketing and sales collateral
quotes.text: And I think labs as well as application layer companies will increasingly use evals to demonstrate the capabilities of their models and their products.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A forward-looking GTM insight: evals becoming a primary way to market and sell AI capability.

quotes.topic_title: AI training market landscape and Mercor origin
quotes.text: If you think about the companies growing faster than any company's ever grown in history, there's essentially three buckets. There's the foundational model companies, there's vibe coding apps, Cursor and Loveable and Bolt and Replit and all these here, and then there's data labeling data companies like you.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a simple market map (three buckets) for understanding where the fastest-growing AI companies fit.

quotes.topic_title: AI training market landscape and Mercor origin
quotes.text: We automated all of those processes with LLMs, bootstrap the company to a million dollar revenue run rate before we dropped out of college.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Concrete example of using LLM automation end-to-end to reach meaningful revenue quickly.

quotes.topic_title: AI training market landscape and Mercor origin
quotes.text: we saw that there was this enormous transition in the human data market where it was moving away from this crowdsourcing problem of how do you find low and medium skilled people that can write barely grammatically correct sentences for early versions of LLMs and moving towards this sourcing and vetting problem.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Highlights a key industry shift practitioners can act on: from low-skill crowdsourcing to high-skill sourcing and vetting.

quotes.topic_title: AI training market landscape and Mercor origin
quotes.text: How do we source and assess the best professionals, the experienced? Think software engineers, the investment bankers and doctors and lawyers that can actually help to evaluate and interpret all of the capabilities that people want models to have.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Defines the new methodology for AI training/evals: recruiting and assessing domain experts to evaluate model capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: AI training market landscape and Mercor origin
quotes.text: We grew from 1 to 400 million in revenue run rate in 16 months, and it's been an extraordinary journey and super exciting.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A striking growth data point illustrating how quickly expert-driven AI data/evals businesses can scale.

quotes.topic_title: Why expert eval labor is so valuable
quotes.text: We grew from 1 to 400 million in revenue run rate in 16 months, and it's been an extraordinary journey and super exciting.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A concrete data point illustrating the explosive demand for expert labor supporting AI labs.

quotes.topic_title: Why expert eval labor is so valuable
quotes.text: the lab's primary bottleneck to being able to improve models is how they can effectively have some way of measuring what success looks like for the model, both to use it as the eval for the tests that they're measuring their progress against, as well as the verifiers in an RL environment to then reward the model, improve capabilities, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A practitioner-relevant framework: progress in model capability is constrained by measurement (evals/verifiers), not just training compute or data.

quotes.topic_title: Why expert eval labor is so valuable
quotes.text: And they need this across every domain for every capability that models don't know how to use.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Highlights the scaling law of eval work: it expands with domain coverage and capability gaps, making expert input structurally valuable.

quotes.topic_title: Why expert eval labor is so valuable
quotes.text: And the wealthiest companies in the world are willing to spend whatever it takes to improve model capabilities where Mercor is sitting at the forefront and the primary bottleneck.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A counterintuitive market signal: the highest leverage spend is on evaluation/verification capacity, not just model training.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day: rubrics and verifiers
quotes.text: Effectively, the market is bound by the amount of things where humans can do something that models can't.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A clear mental model for where AI services businesses can grow: focus on the remaining gap between human capability and model capability.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day: rubrics and verifiers
quotes.text: What you could do is have a lawyer create a rubric similar to how a professor might create a rubric to create a deliverable for what are the things we want the model to be able to do?
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable methodology for turning expert judgment into an evaluation artifact that can guide model improvement.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day: rubrics and verifiers
quotes.text: And that's really the foundation to measuring what does progress look like for models? Is this model achieving the capabilities that these professionals want? As well as how do we use this as training data to reward and to reinforce a lot of the capabilities that people want models to achieve.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Connects eval rubrics directly to both measurement and training signals, showing how the same artifact drives iteration loops.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day: rubrics and verifiers
quotes.text: Well, that's an interesting thing is everyone talks about RL environment. I feel like the two hot button things are like RL environments and evals, but one thing like Andrej Karpathy's tweeted out about a bunch is there's not actually a nuance. It's in the data type. It's more just a different semantic way of describing what it's being used for.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing: “evals” vs “RL environments” are often the same underlying data artifact, just used differently.

quotes.topic_title: What experts do day-to-day: rubrics and verifiers
quotes.text: But ultimately, it's just some stasis point for how do you measure what good looks like?
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A memorable definition practitioners can use to align stakeholders on what an eval (or RL environment) fundamentally is.

quotes.topic_title: From SFT and RLHF to AI feedback
quotes.text: The data landscape historically has included two kinds of data. The first is supervised fine-tuning data, which is input/output. When people think about fine-tuning in the historical sense, that's what it is. The second is RLHF where the model will generate a couple of examples. We'll choose which is the most popular example.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A crisp taxonomy of the two dominant historical training-data paradigms practitioners can use to orient decisions about how to improve models.

quotes.topic_title: From SFT and RLHF to AI feedback
quotes.text: What everyone is generally moving towards is reinforcement learning from AI feedback instead of human feedback where you have instead the human defined some sort of success criteria, some way to measure that.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A shift in methodology: humans specify measurable success criteria, and AI scales the evaluation loop.

quotes.topic_title: From SFT and RLHF to AI feedback
quotes.text: And examples in code, it could be a unit test. We can scalably measure success and other domains that could be a rubric.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Concrete, transferable examples of “success criteria” artifacts (unit tests, rubrics) teams can implement to operationalize evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: From SFT and RLHF to AI feedback
quotes.text: And then you use that to incentivize model capabilities. And it's far more scalable and data-efficient, and so that's why a lot of the broader trend in the market across the board is moving towards RLHF to both eval models as well as improved capabilities.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lever: better evals/rubrics aren’t just measurement—they directly drive capability gains, with scalability and data-efficiency benefits.

quotes.topic_title: From SFT and RLHF to AI feedback
quotes.text: Exactly. Applying all of the criteria of what good looks like similar to how the TA might apply the professor's criteria of does the student's response meet this criteria or this criteria plus however many planes, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for AI-graded evaluation: the AI acts like a TA applying a professor’s rubric to assess outputs consistently.

quotes.topic_title: How long humans will be needed for evals
quotes.text: Our perspective is that these models are extraordinary and automating a lot of things very quickly, but there's a lot of things that they're horrible at.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A practical framing for practitioners: assume rapid automation, but plan around persistent failure modes where humans and evals remain essential.

quotes.topic_title: How long humans will be needed for evals
quotes.text: Even still, it can't schedule time on my calendar. It can't draft emails for me. It can't use basic tools. And we need evals for everything. For everything that the models can't do, we need evals for the tool use, evals for the long horizon reasoning.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Concrete examples plus an actionable methodology: use evals as the mechanism to systematically close gaps in tool use and long-horizon tasks.

quotes.topic_title: How long humans will be needed for evals
quotes.text: Imagine in 10 years when we want models to be able to go out and build a startup for 30 days. We need evals for that to effectively reward it.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A memorable long-horizon benchmark that suggests how to design future evals around real-world, multi-week agentic outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: How long humans will be needed for evals
quotes.text: But very few companies and people have talked about this new category of jobs that's being created and what that's going to mean and how people can prepare and upskill for that.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Contrarian labor-market lens: shifts the conversation from displacement to the emergence of new work categories (e.g., eval design, verification, rubric-building).

quotes.topic_title: Skills and jobs that remain valuable
quotes.text: In terms of jobs, I would respond with a category of things that have very elastic demand are going to be super exciting. Because when we make people 10 times more productive, we'll build 10 times, if not 100 times as much software as an example.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Introduces an “elastic demand” lens for choosing resilient careers where AI-driven productivity increases expand output rather than shrink jobs.

quotes.topic_title: Skills and jobs that remain valuable
quotes.text: And what we realized is that you don't want to fight against them using the models. It's similar to when the calculator came out, you don't want to give people all of this arithmetic work of how do you get them to do it and not use the calculator. You want to tell them, "Use the tools and let's see what you can do."
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A contrarian assessment philosophy: evaluate real-world tool use instead of trying to ban AI, mirroring how calculators changed math education.

quotes.topic_title: Skills and jobs that remain valuable
quotes.text: And so we'll give people interviews where we say, "Use ChatGPT and Kodak. Use Claude code. Use whatever tool cursor and whatever tools are available to build a website and let's see what product you're able to build in an hour."
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A concrete, practitioner-ready hiring method: time-boxed, tool-allowed build tasks to measure modern productivity and judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Skills and jobs that remain valuable
quotes.text: And so I would focus on those domains where if we make everyone 10 times more productive, that'll increase demand, not reduce it.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A simple decision rule for career planning: pick fields where productivity gains create more work and opportunity rather than commoditizing it.

quotes.topic_title: Skills and jobs that remain valuable
quotes.text: But I think the companies and people that are going to succeed are those that lean into this narrative of abundance of how do we do so much more rather than fighting back against it of how do we try to stop displacement.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Reframes AI adoption as an “abundance” strategy—optimize for doing dramatically more, not for preserving old workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Unified labor markets and AI-driven hiring
quotes.text: we were 19, and just had this gut intuition that it felt so wildly inefficient that labor markets are so disaggregated.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Frames a core mental model: today’s hiring inefficiency comes from fragmented markets rather than a lack of talent.

quotes.topic_title: Unified labor markets and AI-driven hiring
quotes.text: when we would hire someone internationally, they would apply to a dozen jobs. When we as a company in the Bay Area were considering candidates, we would consider a fraction of a percent of candidates that were available in the market.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A concrete example/data point showing asymmetry between candidate reach and employer consideration, motivating better matching systems.

quotes.topic_title: Unified labor markets and AI-driven hiring
quotes.text: But when we're able to automate that matching problem at the cost of software, it makes way for this global unified labor market that every candidate applies to and every company hires from facilitating a perfect flow of information in the economy.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A clear framework for how automation turns manual matching into a unified global market with better information flow.

quotes.topic_title: Unified labor markets and AI-driven hiring
quotes.text: AI is just making it easy to adjust their resumes and cover letters and make it feel like, "Oh, I applied to more of course very specifically, but it was one of 100 places."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the new reality of application inflation—practitioners should expect higher volume and lower signal per application.

quotes.topic_title: Unified labor markets and AI-driven hiring
quotes.text: So even if we didn't want to get to this place, we're almost being pushed into this direction of so much volume on both sides. We need something really smart at filtering and helping us hire and select, and this is exactly what you guys have been building for a long time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway: AI-driven filtering/selection becomes necessary as volume rises, not just a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Enterpret unifies all customer conversations in real time, from Gong recordings to Zendesk tickets to Twitter threads, and makes it available for your team for analysis and for action.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical methodology for building a unified, real-time voice-of-customer pipeline across disparate sources so teams can analyze and act quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What makes Enterpret unique is its ability to build and update a customer-specific knowledge graph that provides the most granular and accurate categorization of all customer feedback and connects that customer feedback to critical metrics like revenue and CSAT.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete approach for turning qualitative feedback into structured insights and tying it directly to business outcomes (revenue/CSAT).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I was talking to a friend who had an ankle sprain or his foot was hurting and he got an x-ray and he fed the x-ray into ChatGPT and then asked him, "Give me this specific x-ray."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific example of practitioners using multimodal LLMs for ad-hoc medical interpretation workflows, illustrating real-world usage patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: No, it's actually somebody sitting there helping the model understand this. Once they recognize, it doesn't fully understand this. Humans are actually helping them learn these things.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that model capability often depends on ongoing human input and evaluation rather than just “internet training data.”

quotes.topic_title: Post-training experts, scale, and competition
quotes.text: pre-training gets a lot of the knowledge into the model of what are all the different things that see into the world. And then post-training and reinforcement learning is for all of the reasoning of what are the pieces of knowledge that are accurate, what are inaccurate, and what to prioritize at any given time to make a decision.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Clear mental model for separating pre-training (knowledge) from post-training/RL (reasoning, accuracy, prioritization) when designing evals and expert workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Post-training experts, scale, and competition
quotes.text: there would've been radiologists that worked on the post-training data set to create some stasis point for here's the diagnosis and rewards and penalties associated with it. And it's really the quality of those people that went into the quality of the decision and recommendation that ChatGPT ultimately made.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Actionable emphasis that expert quality directly drives model decision quality, with a concrete example (radiologists) and the RL framing of rewards/penalties.

quotes.topic_title: Post-training experts, scale, and competition
quotes.text: Tens of thousands at any given time, hundreds of thousands more generally. It's huge. And the most exciting thing is that it's growing really quickly.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Hard scale datapoint that quantifies how large post-training expert workforces already are and how fast the market is expanding.

quotes.topic_title: Post-training experts, scale, and competition
quotes.text: what people realized is that actually you can go a lot further with just getting higher caliber people even in smaller amounts initially, and now subsequently scaling that back up once they're able to meet the quality bar.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Counterintuitive operating strategy: start with fewer, higher-caliber experts to hit a quality bar, then scale volume afterward.

quotes.topic_title: Post-training experts, scale, and competition
quotes.text: it actually looks more similar in some ways to one of the traditional labor marketplaces of an Uber or DoorDash, just with much higher-skilled talent that's treated exceptionally well?
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Memorable analogy/framework for thinking about expert post-training as a high-skill labor marketplace with retention and incentives as core design problems.

quotes.topic_title: Creative vs technical experts and talent economics
quotes.text: We hired all the people from the Harvard Lampoon a couple of months ago, their comedy club, to help with making models funnier.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Concrete example of using creative-domain experts (not just technical specialists) to drive model capability improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Creative vs technical experts and talent economics
quotes.text: It would be a customer gives us a request of we need these award-winning screenwriters, and within 24 hours we'll turn around the experts.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Operational benchmark for practitioner teams: expert sourcing and deployment can be executed on a 24-hour turnaround.

quotes.topic_title: Creative vs technical experts and talent economics
quotes.text: And then there's also this really interesting dynamic where in a set of 100 people that we hire, oftentimes the top 10% of people will drive majority of the model improvement.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A talent-economics mental model (power-law impact) that suggests optimizing for identifying the top decile matters more than scaling headcount.

quotes.topic_title: Creative vs technical experts and talent economics
quotes.text: So our median pay rate in the marketplace is $95 an hour, but it can flex up, well up into $500 an hour based on the depth of someone's expertise.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Specific pricing data practitioners can use to budget for high-skill expert evaluation and feedback work.

quotes.topic_title: Creative vs technical experts and talent economics
quotes.text: And ultimately it comes down to what are the capabilities that labs want their models to have? And it much more falls in the latter bucket than the former one.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Contrarian takeaway that labs should prioritize premium professional expertise over low-cost crowdsourcing when targeting economically valuable capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Why some models excel: reward design and evals
quotes.text: Well, I can't go too much into detail about customer work, but I think that it's this trend of reinforcement learning and being very thoughtful about defining the right rewards that we're releasing across the board.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology: model performance gains often come from RL plus careful reward definition, not just bigger models.

quotes.topic_title: Why some models excel: reward design and evals
quotes.text: And how we could mitigate reward hacking, set up the right rewards, that's super impactful.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for practitioners: anticipate and prevent reward hacking as part of reward/eval design to improve real-world model behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Why some models excel: reward design and evals
quotes.text: One of my favorite quotes from customers is that, "Models are only as good as their evals," which has always held true.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that ties model quality directly to evaluation quality, emphasizing evals as the core lever for improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Why some models excel: reward design and evals
quotes.text: I think Greg Brockman tweeted this once. "Evals are all you need."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A quotable, contrarian-sounding mantra that reframes progress as primarily an evaluation problem rather than a purely modeling problem.

quotes.topic_title: How Mercor achieved hypergrowth
quotes.text: I think the most important thing is looking at the leading indicators in fast-moving markets.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A core operating principle: prioritize early signals over lagging metrics when markets are changing quickly.

quotes.topic_title: How Mercor achieved hypergrowth
quotes.text: We have had for the last... We're starting to have a couple of product managers help out with go-to-market, but for the last year and a half of the business, we've had no one in sales and marketing.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A counterintuitive GTM choice: hypergrowth driven by product/customer experience rather than sales/marketing headcount.

quotes.topic_title: How Mercor achieved hypergrowth
quotes.text: Because if it's difficult to sell, if it's extremely difficult to sell the marginal customer, you're not going to be able to grow a huge business. What you actually need to find is the customer that's surprisingly easy to sell into where you're going to be able to grow with them.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A practical PMF test: optimize for “easy to sell” pull rather than forcing adoption through effortful selling.

quotes.topic_title: How Mercor achieved hypergrowth
quotes.text: So it's some combination of being stubborn with respect to your thesis around how the world will change, but also very open-minded with respect to exactly what form that takes and how the market's developing and how your company will fit into it.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A balanced founder mindset: hold conviction on direction while staying flexible on implementation and positioning.

quotes.topic_title: How Mercor achieved hypergrowth
quotes.text: We've never burned money. We were lifetime profitable.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A concrete data point illustrating capital efficiency as part of Mercor’s hypergrowth story.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operating tenets (partial)
quotes.text: So the first one is having a can-do attitude, which everyone gives me a little bit of a hard time for because it's a funny saying, but we've always set these ridiculously ambitious goals, and then somehow the trajectory of the company forms around those goals.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A practical operating tenet: set extremely ambitious goals and let execution and company direction organize around them.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operating tenets (partial)
quotes.text: Where I remember when we were talking to Benchmark before they led our Series A, we were at 1.5 million in run rate. And I said we'd be at 50 million in run rate by the end of the year.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A concrete example of using audacious targets to drive scale expectations far beyond current reality.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operating tenets (partial)
quotes.text: And they said we were absolutely insane, right, as anyone would. And plus or minus two weeks, we hit it.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Counterintuitive proof point that “insane” goals can be achievable and useful as execution forcing functions.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operating tenets (partial)
quotes.text: And then we've now well blown past the tracking to 500 million in run rate, which was initially our goal for this year.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: A specific scaling milestone that reinforces the compounding effect of setting and revising aggressive targets.

quotes.topic_title: Company values and operating tenets (partial)
quotes.text: So setting these incredibly ambitious goals with respect to the revenue scale of the business, the caliber of experiences for talent, all those dimensions is super important to first have a can-do attitude.
quotes.speaker: Brendan Foody
quotes.context: Actionable advice to apply ambitious goal-setting across multiple dimensions (revenue and talent experience), not just one metric.
